Award.AwardTitle: Atmospheric Blocking: Dynamics and Responses to Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Atmospheric blocking events are an important contributor to high impact extreme weather events. Improving the forecasts of blocking events and assessing how the frequency, severity, and location of such events may change with climate change are of substantial societal importance. Synoptic eddies have been shown to play a critical role in the dynamics of atmospheric blocking events by maintaining the blocking pattern but the understanding of their role is currently not sufficiently complete and quantitative.

The goals of the proposed research are 1) to improve the dynamical understanding of atmospheric blocking events through developing a quantitative assessment of synoptic-eddy forcing of blocks. 2) to employ this dynamical understanding to investigate how blocking events will change with climate change and how blocks can be better simulated in climate and weather models. The proposed research will employ numerical experiments with a hierarchy of general circulation models, reanalysis data, and archived results of full-physics general circulation models such as Coupled Model Intercomparison Project models. The research has three components: the first is to study the eddy-forcing mechanism using idealized modeling experiments which to isolate and develop a quantitative understanding of this mechanism. The same idealized framework will be used to investigate how the speed and latitude of jet streams, different patterns of quasi-stationary planetary waves, and moisture modulate this mechanism. The second component is to test this understanding using the reanalysis data and to gain further insight into the dynamic of observed blocking events. The third component is to apply this understanding to examine the performance of full-physics models in simulating blocking, and to provide a more reliable and conclusive prediction on how blocking events will change in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project is to better understand blocking dynamics, their impact on extreme weather, and their response to climate changes. Below are our activities and findings over the course of the project.

 

1. We have worked on evaluating and improving several conventional blocking indices by examining the linear relation of the identified patterns with surface hot extremes in reanalysis data (Chan, Hassanzadeh and Kuang, 2019). We have also explored potential applications of deep learning pattern recognition methods as blocking indices, describing a test case for application of convolutional neural networks to spatio-temporal climate data, aimed at finding specific weather patterns over North America in LENS data (Chattopadhyay, Hassanzadeh and Pasha, 2020).

 

2. We have tested the eddy mean flow feedback idea by Shutts (1988) for the maintenance of blocking. In particular, we have found evidence against the eddy straining idea and evidence that points to blocking as a wave packet. We continue to carefully develop this idea, with a hierarchical of models with different complexities. This work was iscussed in this report in Science https://www.sciencemag.org/news/2020/03/why-does-weather-stall-new-theories-explain-enigmatic-blocks-jet-stream).

 

3. We have worked on understanding how the spatio-temporal characteristics of blocking events scale with various parameters such as the atmosphere’s static stability and the midlatitude jet’s variability. We have found a robust weakening of the blocking events in winters (without a change in the structure) and a complex, regionally dependent change in their structures in summers. We are currently working on finalizing the analysis to submit these results for publication (Nabizadeh, Lubis & Hassanzadeh, to be submitted to J. Climate). A paper related to this subject, focused on understanding how the width of the jet changes with Arctic amplification is published (Ronalds, Barnes and Hassanzadeh, J. Climate 2018). 

 

4. Four studies on the variability of the midlatitude jet are published (Ma et al., 2017, Ronalds et al. 2018, Wang et al., 2018, Hassanzadeh and Kuang, 2019). In Ma et al. (2017) a new method for quantifying the eddy-jet feedback in the annular mode dynamics is formulated and an improved estimate of the feedback in the Southern Annular Mode dynamics is presented.  In Hassanzadeh and Kuang, the mechanism of this feedback is studied in an idealized atmosphere and the role of different processes (i.e., eddy momentum and eddy heat fluxes, radiation, surface friction) is quantified. In Ronalds et al., the effect of Arctic Amplification on the jet’s variability via changing the jet’s width is explored and the underlying mechanism is studied. In Wang et al., we looked at the dynamics of intraseasonal variations in the midlatitude jetstream, including the role of moist convection and potential changes with a warming climate.

 

5. We studied the connection between the variability of the north Pacific blocking events and ENSO (Anderson et al., 2017). It is found that the frequency of blocking events during a given winter serves as a key modulator of intraseasonal variability in extratropical North Pacific circulations and, through their influence on the seasonal-mean circulations in and around the southern lobe of the North Pacific Oscillation, the state of the equatorial Pacific 9-12 months later. The results further highlight the connection between blocking events and other modes of climate variability.

 

6. We investigated how blocking events over western and midwestern US affect the movement of landfalling Texas tropical cyclones (TCs). From the track of the three most devastating Texas TCs of the 21st century (Allison, Ike and Harvey) and the large-scale circulation pattern around the time of their landfall, we found a clear impact of extratropical persistent high-pressure patterns over North America on the movement of these TCs, leading to very slow-moving “stalled” storms (Allision and Harvey), or a fast-moving storm (Ike). We then used a number of large-ensemble datasets to study how the large-scale circulation over North America will change under climate change and the impact of these changes on the movement of future landfilling Texas TCs. The results show the importance of understanding how the size, persistence, and location of these persistent weather patterns will change in the future (Hassanzadeh et al., in revision at Nature Communications).   

7. We have studied how equilibrated baroclinic eddies change with changes in stratification only and no changes in the zonal mean zonal wind. This was motivated by the suggestion that jets tend to move poleward as the climate warms; our new idea about blocking suggests more blocking as the jets move poleward. We were able to precisely control the mean state of a GCM to only change the stratification with minimal change in the wind. We show that the eddy length scale becomes smaller, opposite to previous results. We are fully documenting the changes in equilibrated baroclinic eddies in this case, which should be a valuable benchmark for theories of baroclinic turbulence.
